tool.name: OpenSwathRTNormalizer
tool.description: This tool will take a description of RT peptides and their normalized retention time to write out a transformation file on how to transform the RT space into the normalized space.
tool.command:
@QUOTE_FOO@ @EXT_FOO@ #import re
## Preprocessing mkdir in && mkdir ${' '.join(["'in/%s'" % (i) for i, f in enumerate($in) if f])} && ${' '.join(["ln -s '%s' 'in/%s/%s.%s' && " % (f, i, re.sub('[^\w\-_]', '_', f.element_identifier), $gxy2omsext(f.ext)) for i, f in enumerate($in) if f])} mkdir tr && ln -s '$tr' 'tr/${re.sub("[^\w\-_]", "_", $tr.element_identifier)}.$gxy2omsext($tr.ext)' && mkdir out && #if $rt_norm: mkdir rt_norm && ln -s '$rt_norm' 'rt_norm/${re.sub("[^\w\-_]", "_", $rt_norm.element_identifier)}.$gxy2omsext($rt_norm.ext)' && #end if
## Main program call
set -o pipefail && @EXECUTABLE@ -write_ctd ./ && python3 '$__tool_directory__/fill_ctd.py' '@EXECUTABLE@.ctd' '$args_json' '$hardcoded_json' && @EXECUTABLE@ -ini @EXECUTABLE@.ctd -in ${' '.join(["'in/%s/%s.%s'"%(i, re.sub('[^\w\-_]', '_', f.element_identifier), $gxy2omsext(f.ext)) for i, f in enumerate($in) if f])} -tr 'tr/${re.sub("[^\w\-_]", "_", $tr.element_identifier)}.$gxy2omsext($tr.ext)' -out 'out/output.${gxy2omsext("trafoxml")}' #if $rt_norm: -rt_norm 'rt_norm/${re.sub("[^\w\-_]", "_", $rt_norm.element_identifier)}.$gxy2omsext($rt_norm.ext)' #end if
## Postprocessing && mv 'out/output.${gxy2omsext("trafoxml")}' '$out' #if "ctd_out_FLAG" in $OPTIONAL_OUTPUTS && mv '@EXECUTABLE@.ctd' '$ctd_out' #end if

param.label: Input files separated by blank
param.help: select mzml data sets(s)

param.label: transition file with the RT peptides ('TraML' or 'csv')
param.help: select csv,traml data sets(s)

param.label: RT normalization file (how to map the RTs of this run to the ones stored in the library)
param.help: select trafoxml data sets(s)

param.label: Minimum r-squared of RT peptides regression
Minimum relative amount of RT peptides to keep
Whether the algorithms should try to choose the best peptides based on their peak shape for normalization
param.help: Use this option you do not expect all your peptides to be detected in a sample and too many 'bad' peptides enter the outlier removal step (e.g. due to them being endogenous peptides or using a less curated list of peptides)

section.name: RTNormalization
section.title: Parameters for the RTNormalization
section.help: RT normalization and outlier detection can be done iteratively (by default) which removes one outlier per iteration or using the RANSAC algorithm

param.label: Which outlier detection method to use (valid: 'iter_residual', 'iter_jackknife', 'ransac', 'none')
param.help: Iterative methods remove one outlier at a time. Jackknife approach optimizes for maximum r-squared improvement while 'iter_residual' removes the datapoint with the largest residual error (removal by residual is computationally cheaper, use this with lots of peptides)

param.label: Whether to use Chauvenet's criterion when using iterative methods
param.help: This should be used if the algorithm removes too many datapoints but it may lead to true outliers being retained

param.label: Maximum iterations for the RANSAC outlier detection algorithm
Maximum threshold in RT dimension for the RANSAC outlier detection algorithm (in percent of the total gradient)
param.help: Default is set to 3% which is around +/- 4 minutes on a 120 gradient

param.label: Sampling size of data points per iteration for the RANSAC outlier detection algorithm
Stop reporting after feature (ordered by quality; -1 means do not stop)
Only extract RT around this value (-1 means extract over the whole range, a value of 500 means to extract around +/- 500 s of the expected elution)
param.help: For this to work, the TraML input file needs to contain normalized RT values

param.label: The normalized RT is expected to be between 0 and 1
param.help: If your normalized RT has a different range, pass this here (e.g. it goes from 0 to 100, set this value to 100)

param.label: Cutoff in m/z below which peaks should not be used for quantification any more
Whether to write out all points of all features into the featureXML
For spectrum addition, either use simple concatenation or use peak resampling
Add up spectra around the peak apex (needs to be a non-even integer)
If spectra are to be added, use this spacing to add them up
S/N threshold to consider identification transition (set to -1 to consider all)
Peak area threshold to consider identification transition (set to -1 to consider all)
Scoring model to use
Extra drift time to extract for IM scoring (as a fraction
param.help: e.g. 0.25 means 25% extra on each side)

param.label: Whether to error (true) or skip (false) if a transition in a transition group does not have a corresponding chromatogram
Stop finding after feature (ordered by intensity; -1 means do not stop)
Stop after reaching intensity ratio
Minimal peak width (s), discard all peaks below this value (-1 means no action)
Calculate the peak area and height either the smoothed or the raw chromatogram data
Remove background from peak signal using estimated noise levels
param.help: The 'original' method is only provided for historical purposes, please use the 'exact' method and set parameters using the PeakIntegrator: settings. The same original or smoothed chromatogram specified by peak_integration will be used for background estimation

param.label: Tries to get better peak picking by looking at peak consistency of all picked peaks
param.help: Tries to use the consensus (median) peak border if the variation within the picked peaks is too large

param.label: Use precursor chromatogram for peak picking (note that this may lead to precursor signal driving the peak picking)
Use consensus peak boundaries when computing transition group picking (if false, compute independent peak boundaries for each transition)
Determines the maximal Z-Score (difference measured in standard deviations) that is considered too large for peak boundaries
param.help: If the Z-Score is above this value, the median is used for peak boundaries (default value 1.0)

param.label: Only if compute_peak_quality is set, this parameter will not consider peaks below this quality threshold
For computing peak quality, how many extra seconds should be sample left and right of the actual peak
Tries to compute a quality value for each peakgroup and detect outlier transitions
param.help: The resulting score is centered around zero and values above 0 are generally good and below -1 or -2 are usually bad

param.label: Calculates various peak shape metrics
param.help: (e.g., tailing) that can be used for downstream QC/QA

param.label: Compute mutual information metrics for individual transitions that can be used for OpenSWATH/IPF scoring
Method to use when selecting the best boundaries for peaks
The number of subsequent data points used for smoothing
param.help: This number has to be uneven. If it is not, 1 will be added

param.label: Order of the polynomial that is fitted
Gaussian width in seconds, estimated peak size
Use Gaussian filter for smoothing (alternative is Savitzky-Golay filter)
Force a certain minimal peak_width on the data
param.help: (e.g. extend the peak at least by this amount on both sides) in seconds. -1 turns this feature off

param.label: Signal-to-noise threshold at which a peak will not be extended any more
param.help: Note that setting this too high (e.g. 1.0) can lead to peaks whose flanks are not fully captured

param.label: Signal to noise window length
Signal to noise bin count
Write out log messages of the signal-to-noise estimator in case of sparse windows or median in rightmost histogram bin
Try to remove overlapping peaks during peak picking
Which method to choose for chromatographic peak-picking (OpenSWATH legacy on raw data, corrected picking on smoothed chromatogram or Crawdad on smoothed chromatogram)
The integration technique to use in integratePeak() and estimateBackground() which uses either the summed intensity, integration by Simpson's rule or trapezoidal integration
The baseline type to use in estimateBackground() based on the peak boundaries
param.help: A rectangular baseline shape is computed based either on the minimal intensity of the peak boundaries, the maximum intensity or the average intensity (base_to_base)

param.label: Fit the chromatogram/spectrum to the EMG peak model
DIA extraction window in Th or ppm
DIA extraction window unit
Use centroided DIA data
DIA b/y series minimum intensity to conside
DIA b/y series minimal difference in ppm to conside
DIA number of isotopes to conside
DIA number of charges to conside
DIA maximal difference in ppm to count a peak at lower m/z when searching for evidence that a peak might not be monoisotopic
Sampling rate for the interpolation of the model function
Bounding box has range [minimim of data, maximum of data] enlarged by tolerance_stdev_bounding_box times the standard deviation of the data
Maximum number of iterations using by Levenberg-Marquardt algorithm
Initialize parameters using method of moments estimators
Centroid position of the model
Variance of the model
Use the shape score (this score measures the similarity in shape of the transitions using a cross-correlation)
Use the coelution score (this score measures the similarity in coelution of the transitions using a cross-correlation)
Use the retention time score (this score measure the difference in retention time)
Use the library score
Use the elution model (EMG) score (this score fits a gaussian model to the peak and checks the fit)
Use the intensity score
Use the number of peaks score
Use the total XIC score
Use the total MI score
Use the SN (signal to noise) score
Use the MI (mutual information) score
Use the DIA (SWATH) scores
param.help: If turned off, will not use fragment ion spectra for scoring

param.label: Use the correlation scores with the MS1 elution profiles
Use the scores for SONAR scans (scanning swath)
Use the scores for Ion Mobility scans
Use the full MS1 scan at the peak apex for scoring (ppm accuracy of precursor and isotopic pattern)
Use the MS1 MI score
Use UIS scores for peptidoform identification
Use MS2-level b/y ion-series scores for peptidoform identification
Use MS2-level isotope scores (pearson & manhattan) across product transitions (based on ID if annotated or averagine)

section.name: peptideEstimation
section.title: Parameters for the peptide estimation (use -estimateBestPeptides to enable)

param.label: The initial overall quality cutoff for a peak to be scored (range ca
The overall quality cutoff for a peak to go into the retention time estimation (range ca
Number of RT bins to use to compute coverage
param.help: This option should be used to ensure that there is a complete coverage of the RT space (this should detect cases where only a part of the RT gradient is actually covered by normalization peptides)

param.label: Minimal number of peptides that are required for a bin to counted as 'covered'
Minimal number of bins required to be covered
Enables the test mode (needed for internal use only)

param.name: OPTIONAL_OUTPUTS
param.label: Optional outputs

data.name: ctd_out
data.label: ${tool.name} on ${on_string}: ctd
data.filter: OPTIONAL_OUTPUTS is not None and "ctd_out_FLAG" in OPTIONAL_OUTPUTS

tool.help:
This tool will take a description of RT peptides and their normalized retention time to write out a transformation file on how to transform the RT space into the normalized space.
For more information, visit http://www.openms.de/doxygen/release/2.8.0/html/TOPP_OpenSwathRTNormalizer.html
